Calculate the Moments of a Shape

Source: R/shape.R
moments.Rd

moments calculates all of the moments up to the third order of a polygon or rasterized shape.

moments(contours, id = NULL)

Arguments

contours

A list of two matrices as produced by findContours.
id

An optional vector indicating the identity of the specific contours for which to run the function.

Value

A data frame with 3 columns:

  • "id": the contour identity (indicates the set of points belonging to the same contour).

  • "moment": the name of the moment. See Note below.

  • "value": the value of the moment.

Note

The spatial moments \(\texttt{m} _{ji}\) are computed as: $$\texttt{m} _{ji}= \sum _{x,y} \left ( \texttt{contour} (x,y) \cdot x^j \cdot y^i \right )$$

The central moments \(mu_ij\) are computed as: $$\texttt{mu} _{ji}= \sum _{x,y} \left ( \texttt{contour} (x,y) \cdot (x - \bar{x} )^j \cdot (y - \bar{y} )^i \right )$$ where \((\bar{x}, \bar{y})\) is the mass center: $$\bar{x} = \frac{\texttt{m}_{10}}{\texttt{m}_{00}} , \; \bar{y} = \frac{\texttt{m}_{01}}{\texttt{m}_{00}}$$

The normalized central moments moments \(nu_ij\) are computed as: $$\texttt{nu} _{ji}= \frac{\texttt{mu}_{ji}}{\texttt{m}_{00}^{(i+j)/2+1}} .$$

See also

findContours

Author

Simon Garnier, garnier@njit.edu

Examples

dots <- image(system.file("sample_img/dots.jpg", package = "Rvision"))
dots_gray <- changeColorSpace(dots, "GRAY")
dots_bin <- dots_gray < 200
contours <- findContours(dots_bin)
moments(contours, id = c(3, 5))

#>      id moment         value
#> 3.1   3    m00  8.290500e+03
#> 3.2   3    m10  5.846871e+06
#> 3.3   3    m01  7.960358e+05
#> 3.4   3    m20  4.128506e+09
#> 3.5   3    m11  5.610887e+08
#> 3.6   3    m02  8.243463e+07
